message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a femoral nerve injury, which explains the weakness of hip flexion and knee extension, as well as the decreased patellar reflex and sensation in the distribution of the femoral nerve. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness or reflex changes, and Fibular nerve injury would not affect the distribution of decreased sensation. S1 radiculopathy would affect sensation in the posterior leg and would not cause weakness or reflex changes that are specific to the femoral nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the symptoms and the weakness and decreased reflex suggest femoral nerve injury. None of the other options involve the femoral nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a femoral nerve injury, as the patient has decreased strength on hip flexion and knee extension and decreased sensation on the anteromedial thigh, which are all features of femoral nerve innervation. Sural nerve injury would result in loss of sensation on the lateral foot and fibular nerve injury would result in weakness and sensory loss on the dorsiflexed foot. S1 radiculopathy would affect the posterior thigh and the lateral foot, but not the anteromedial thigh. The fact that the symptoms occurred after hip arthroplasty suggest that the femoral nerve may have been compressed or injured during the surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a femoral nerve injury, which would explain the weakness and decreased patellar reflex. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness, but rather sensory deficits on the lateral foot and ankle. Fibular nerve injury would cause foot weakness and sensory deficits on the lateral leg and dorsum of the foot. S1 radiculopathy would cause weakness in the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, but not in the hip flexors which are affected in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including weakness in hip flexion and knee extension, decreased patellar reflex, and decreased sensation in the anteromedial thigh, suggest femoral nerve injury. Sural nerve injury would affect sensation in the lateral lower leg, fibular nerve injury would affect dorsiflexion and eversion, and S1 radiculopathy would affect sensation and strength in the posterior thigh and calf.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with a femoral nerve injury. The weakened hip flexion and decreased patellar reflex are indicative of nerve compression, and the sensory deficits in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg are consistent with the distribution of the femoral nerve. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness in hip flexion, and the distribution of the sensory deficit is different. Fibular nerve injury would not result in decreased patellar reflex, and the distribution of the sensory deficit is different. S1 radiculopathy would have a different distribution of weakness and sensory deficit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a femoral nerve injury, as the patient has weakness in hip flexion and knee extension and decreased patellar reflex on the left, which are all controlled by the femoral nerve. Sensory deficits in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg are also consistent with femoral nerve involvement. Sural nerve injury would cause sensory deficits in the lateral lower leg and foot. Fibular nerve injury would cause weakness in ankle dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory deficits on the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot. S1 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits and weakness in ankle plantar flexion and eversion as well as decreased Achilles tendon reflex, which are not seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a femoral nerve injury, which controls the muscles that extend the knee and hip and provides sensation to the thigh and lower leg. Sural nerve injury would cause numbness in the lateral foot and fibular nerve injury would cause weakness in the ankle and foot dorsiflexion. S1 radiculopathy would cause weakness in ankle plantar flexion and numbness in the lateral foot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a nerve injury. The location of the symptoms and the weakened strength and reflex suggest a femoral nerve injury. Sural nerve injury will not lead to weakness in hip flexion and knee extension. Fibular nerve injury will not affect the patellar reflex. S1 radiculopathy will also not affect the femoral nerve function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the underlying cause is femoral nerve injury. The femoral nerve supplies the muscles that flex the hip and extend the knee, which is consistent with the patient's left leg strength of 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. The patellar reflex is decreased on the left, which is also consistent with femoral nerve injury. The decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch on the anteromedial left thigh and medial lower leg suggest involvement of the femoral nerve distribution. Sural nerve injury and fibular nerve injury do not affect the femoral nerve distribution, while S1 radiculopathy involves a different nerve root.
